results.title: My valley is changing
results.creator_credit: Lionel Hudson, David Haythornthwaite, John Martin-Jones, Roland Beckett and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows how the people of Bougainvillea are reacting to the changes brought about by the mining operations. They are finding it difficult to adapt but copper export means income for the whole territory and provides jobs and training for people eager for independence.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lionel Hudson, David Haythornthwaite, John Martin-Jones, Roland Beckett and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: My uncle = Mon oncle [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tati, Louis Dolivet, Alterdel-Centaure, Fray and Specta
results.brief_description: Mon Oncle is a poetic satire depicting man against machine, rather in the manner of Chaplin’s “Modern Times” and Rene Clair’s “A Nous la Liberte”. Hulot is little Gerard Arpel’s uncle, a fond relative whose whimsical ways fail to impress the boy’s ultra-modern parents. What transpires is a masterpiece of design which develops Tati’s unique comic vision without ever losing sight of the essential simplicity he holds so dear. Deft, elusive, full of heart, “Mon Oncle” is a film to see again and again. Winner of Academy Award for Best Foreign Film. Also available on VHS [301867].

results.title: My turtle died today
results.brief_description: In this first-person story, a boy recalls the death of a pet. His father, his teacher, and the pet-shop owner are unable to help his sick turtle, and it dies. This story creates an opportunity for discussion of the inevitability of death and the continuity of life. Adapted from the Little Owl book.

results.title: My time again - Richard Burton
results.brief_description: Richard Burton talks about how he became an actor, and discusses the art of acting for stage and screen with Michael Elwyn who is, like Burton, a Welsh actor who moved towards professional acting while a member of the Oxford University Dramatic Society.

results.title: My tiger's eyes
results.creator_credit: Teck Tan and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: The conservative anti-Communist era of the 1950’s, the Cold War and the “Reds under the bed” - in Sydney, Australia, a young Chinese boy grows up and the Irish/Australian neighbours suspect his family might very well be Communists. The paranoia of the O’Hallorans takes on a comic twist when the boy’s Uncle Walter arrives in the country. A refugee from the Chinese Communist Revolution, the O’Hallorans take him for a Communist spy instead. Seen through the not-so-innocent eyes of 10 year-old Robert Ah Louey, the film captures the social attitudes of the 1950’s, the cultural nuances of neighbours on either side of the fence, and in the process saying something of what it was like being Chinese in Australia during the 50’s. Cast includes Adam Gungor (Robert), Terry Woo (Uncle Walter), Genevieve Mooy (Dolores O’Halloran), Peter Whitford (Jack O’Halloran). (Awards: Special Prize, ATOM Awards, 1993; Finalist, Best Fiction Category and EAC Award, Sydney Film Festival, 1992; Nominated Best Short Film AFI Awards, 1992)

results.title: My life without Steve
results.brief_description: Through a study of one woman’s year in a room with a window, “My Life Without Steve” forms a narrative that catches its audience up in the collective memories of all those of us who have at some stage loved and lost. A multi-award winning production. Rated: PG

results.title: My Father, My Country
results.brief_description: In 1938 three Australian patrol officers, Jim Taylor, John Black and Pat Walsh set off on an extraordinary journey into the unexplored highlands of New Guinea. Their major purpose - to make contact with stone age tribes who know nothing of the outside world and explain to them that their lives were about to undergo incredible change. Fifty years later, Jim Taylor’s daughter, Meg, sets out on her own journey of discovery, retracing the footsteps of her father’s epic journey.

results.title: My family: July 20th 1969
results.creator_credit: Felicity Morgan-Rhind and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: As man is about to walk on the moon. Kids are eating spaghetti, grandpa is having a heart attack and parent’s are trying to contact family to tell them they’ve named their new baby - Felicity. Cast includes Michael, Thomas and William Veitch, Jenny and George Davies, Stephanie Millar and James Reeson.

results.title: My dog 'Number'
results.creator_credit: Paul Barralet and British Information Services
results.brief_description: A typical year in the life of David Murray, a Scottish sheep farmer, and of “Number”, his champion sheep-dog; filmed against pleasant Scottish hill-country, with interesting wildlife sequences, through the four seasons.

results.title: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
results.brief_description: My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina and is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling.

constellations_other.name: Magic lanterns and internet culture
constellations_other.description: The basic animation techniques of magic lanterns are strangely similar to internet aesthetics.

results.title_for_label: My Boyfriend Came Back from the War
results.description:
My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina.

My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling. The work consists of nested frames with black and white web pages and (sometimes animated) grainy GIF images. When clicking hyperlinks in the work, the frame splits into smaller frames and the user reveals a nonlinear story about a couple that is reunited after a nameless military conflict. The lovers find it difficult to reconnect; the woman confesses that she has had an affair with a neighbour while the returned soldier proposes marriage. The story unfolds to the point where the screen has become a mosaic of empty black frames.

Olia Lialina calls the work a netfilm, because of its similarity with cinematic narrative. The grainy black-and-white images and intertitles refer to early silent movies. Of its filmic qualities, curator Michael Connor wrote of the work, “the work adapts cinematic montage to the web … separate frames are joined together by HTML code and the browser itself and experienced in both space and in time, employing what Lev Manovich has characterized as spatial and temporal montage.” - Wikipedia
description_for_label:
My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is a browser-based internet artwork created in 1996 by Russian artist Olia Lialina.

My Boyfriend Came Back From the War is an example of interactive hypertext storytelling. The work consists of nested frames with black and white web pages and (sometimes animated) grainy GIF images. When clicking hyperlinks in the work, the frame splits into smaller frames and the user reveals a nonlinear story about a couple that is reunited after a nameless military conflict. The lovers find it difficult to reconnect; the woman confesses that she has had an affair with a neighbour while the returned soldier proposes marriage. The story unfolds to the point where the screen has become a mosaic of empty black frames.

Olia Lialina calls the work a netfilm, because of its similarity with cinematic narrative. The grainy black-and-white images and intertitles refer to early silent movies. Of its filmic qualities, curator Michael Connor wrote of the work, “the work adapts cinematic montage to the web … separate frames are joined together by HTML code and the browser itself and experienced in both space and in time, employing what Lev Manovich has characterized as spatial and temporal montage.” - Wikipedia
